skill.name: python-scripting
skill.description: Python scripting with uv and PEP 723 inline dependencies. Use when creating standalone Python scripts with automatic dependency management.
skill.summary: Python scripting with uv and PEP 723 inline dependencies. Use when creating standalone Python script...
skill.author: Joseph OBrien

security_audit.summary: Template-based skill providing a Python script template with uv and PEP 723 inline dependencies. Contains no executable code that runs on installation. Uses only standard library imports and placeholders for user customization.

content.value_statement: Writing standalone Python scripts with dependencies requires manual setup and configuration. This skill generates ready-to-run scripts with PEP 723 inline metadata, automatic dependency management, and proper CLI argument parsing.
actual_capabilities: Generates standalone Python scripts with PEP 723 inline metadata
Configures automatic dependency installation via uv
Sets up argparse CLI argument parsing
Creates reproducible builds with exclude-newer timestamp
Supports input and output file handling
limitations: Requires uv and Python 3.12+ installed on the system
Only creates scripts - does not execute them
Template placeholders must be filled in by the AI or user
No built-in support for complex dependency resolution

use_cases.title: Automation scripts
use_cases.description: Create reproducible automation scripts for deployment, data processing, and system maintenance tasks.

use_cases.title: Data processing pipelines
use_cases.description: Build standalone data processing scripts with required libraries installed automatically on first run.

use_cases.title: CLI utilities
use_cases.description: Generate command-line tools with proper argument parsing and help documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Basic script
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Python script named 'hello.py' that prints a greeting message. Use requests for HTTP calls and rich for formatted output.

prompt_templates.title: Data processing
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a script 'process_data.py' that reads a CSV file, calculates summary statistics using pandas, and outputs results to JSON format.

prompt_templates.title: API client
prompt_templates.prompt: Create 'api_client.py' that takes a URL as input, makes a GET request using httpx, and displays the response in pretty-printed JSON format.

prompt_templates.title: File converter
prompt_templates.prompt: Create 'convert.py' that converts JSON files to YAML. Support input file and output file as arguments. Use pyyaml for conversion.

output_examples.input: Create a Python script that fetches weather data and displays it nicely.
output: ‚úì Generated weather.py with requests and rich dependencies
Run with: uv run weather.py --city London

best_practices: Include exclude-newer in PEP 723 metadata for reproducible builds across time.
Add docstrings with usage examples so users understand how to run the script.
Use argparse with --help to provide clear command-line documentation.
Return appropriate exit codes: 0 for success, non-zero for errors.
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API keys or credentials in script templates.
Skipping the docstring and usage examples section.
Making scripts do too many unrelated tasks - keep them focused.
Forgetting to specify the Python version requirement.

faq.question: What Python version is required?
faq.answer: Python 3.12 or higher is required for PEP 723 inline script support.

faq.question: Where does uv install dependencies?
faq.answer: uv creates an isolated virtual environment for each script and installs dependencies there.

faq.question: Can I use this skill without uv installed?
faq.answer: No, uv must be installed. Install via: curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

faq.question: Is my data safe when running these scripts?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only generates template code. Scripts run locally with your permissions.

faq.question: Why am I getting a 'command not found' error?
faq.answer: Ensure uv is in your PATH. Add export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH" to your shell config.

faq.question: How is this different from a regular Python virtual environment?
faq.answer: uv scripts inline all dependencies in the file itself, eliminating separate requirements.txt or environment.yml files.
